value.title: Eufy Security Video Smart Lock Combines 2K Camera And Fingerprint Sensor
value.excerpt: Anker's Eufy Security reveals a new video smart lock system that makes smart protection of one's own front door seem simple, handy, and enjoyable.

value.title: Washington to Roll Out Facial Recognition Dropped by IRS
value.excerpt: Washington state is getting ready to roll out the ID.me facial recognition system dropped by the IRS over privacy and equity concerns, while human rights activists are asking state government officials to ban the system.

value.title: What You Need to Know About Facial Recognition at Airports
value.excerpt: Customs officials aim to save time and increase security by ramping up the use of facial recognition. But what about privacy? A biometrics specialist weighs in.

value.title: Texas AG Ken Paxton sues Facebook parent Meta over facial recognition
value.excerpt: The company said in November that it was shutting down its facial recognition program and deleting its data. Texas is asking the court to fine Meta $25,000 for each violation of the informed consent rule and $10,000 for each violation of the state's ...

value.title: Hummingbirds AI to present facial recognition security system at SXSW Pitch event
value.excerpt: Hummingbirds AI was selected as an alternate in the Artificial Intelligence, Robotics & Voice category of SXSW Pitch to display its GuacamoleID application.

value.title: Following Backlash, IRS Allows Skipping Facial Recognition
value.excerpt: The Internal Revenue Service announced Monday it will continue to use its face recognition software deemed controversial for being required to verify the identities of taxpayers to log on to its website.

value.title: New ACM TechBrief spotlights privacy, ethics problems with facial recognition technology
value.excerpt: The Association for Computing Machinery’s global Technology Policy Council (ACM TPC) today released, “ACM TechBrief: Facial Recognition,” a concise overview of an increasingly-used application which relies heavily on artificial intelligence.

value.title: IRS will allow taxpayers to forgo facial recognition amid blowback
value.excerpt: The IRS said Monday that it would allow taxpayers to opt out of using facial recognition technology and would shift to a different identity verification system next year.

value.title: IRS now allows taxpayers to avoid facial recognition following backlash
value.excerpt: The Internal Revenue Service announced Monday it will continue to use its face recognition software deemed controversial for being required to verify the identities of taxpayers to log on to its website.

value.title: IRS now lets taxpayers opt out of facial recognition after backlash
value.excerpt: The IRS announced that people who want to avoid turning over their biometric data as part of the login process can now talk to a human via video chat instead to prove they are who they say they are.

value.title: Cipia brings AI and computer vision monitoring systems to eliminate the dangers of distracted driving

value.title: IRS doesn't completely scrap facial recognition, just makes it optional
value.excerpt: Folks setting up an online IRS account will be given the choice of providing biometric data, or speaking with a human agent in a video call, to authenticate. Those who are comfortable with facial recognition can submit a selfie,

value.title: IRS offers alternative to facial recognition
value.excerpt: A short-term option involves a virtual interview with IRS personnel to authenticate taxpayers’ and practitioners’ identities for online services.

value.title: Facial recognition technology faces mounting legal, ethical questions
value.excerpt: Facebook's parent company, Meta, is under scrutiny for its use of facial recognition technology from 2009 until late 2021. The Texas Attorney General, Ken Paxton, filed a lawsuit in mid-February, seeking damages related to Facebook's photo services.

value.title: IRS will let tax payers opt out of facial recognition, but there's a big catch
value.excerpt: Although the IRS has dropped its plans to use video selfies to verify the identities of taxpayers, this year's tax season is still set to be a bit more chaotic than usual. Originally the government agency had planned to use the third-party identity verification provider ID.

value.title: The Future of Computer Vision and AI in Clinical and Hospital Settings

value.title: IRS Adds Option That Lets Taxpayers Skip Facial Recognition
value.excerpt: The Internal Revenue Service on Monday said it has enabled a new option that allows taxpayers to sign up for online accounts with the agency without the use of any biometric data, including facial recognition.

value.title: Air Force moves to drive computer vision research and development
value.excerpt: An official said it shows that DOD is serious about enabling more personnel to harness artificial intelligence.

value.title: Facial recognition firm aims to collect 100 billion photos by 2023
value.excerpt: Clearview AI told investors it would have 100 billion facial photos in its databases by the end of the year. The company claims its "index of faces" has grown from 3 billion to 10 billion since 2020.

value.title: Facial recognition technology taken to the next level in virtual reality
value.excerpt: An international team of researchers from Australia, New Zealand and India has taken facial recognition technology to the next level, using a person’s expression to manipulate objects in a virtual reality setting without the use of a handheld controller or touchpad.

value.title: Clearview AI aims to put almost every human in facial recognition database
value.excerpt: The controversial facial recognition company Clearview AI reportedly told investors that it aims to collect 100 billion photos—supposedly enough to ensure that almost every human will be in its database.
